child.pub-comments: Rubin bases his Ethiopian group on Hetzron (1972), who classifies Northern Gurage as being both in the n-group and the tt-group of Outer South Ethiopic, since he was not sure in which group to place it.

This is based on Robern Hetzron's work Hetzron, Robert. 1972. Ethiopian Semitic: Studies in Classification. Manchester, UK: Manchester University Press), where instead of using a binary tree, he has both the groups called "n-group" and "tt-group" as the mothers of Northern Gurage.

child.alt-names: Eastern Modern Aramaic, Eastern Late Aramaic
child.pub-comments: How Rubin wants Neo-Aramaic dialects treated is not clear. He deals with them almost as if they were a single group, but since he gives no name to the node above, he clearly does not want to claim they are indeed a group. In addition he explicit says that they are not descended from earlier known dialects, but that they fall into the Western and Eastern groups that the earlier dialects did. We therefore treat the neo-Aramaic dialects as simply descending from the earlier groupings, and not as a coherent group in and of themselves.

child.pub-comments: How Rubin wants Neo-Aramaic dialects treated is not clear. He deals with them almost as if they were a single group, but since he gives no name to the node above, he clearly does not want to claim they are indeed a group. In addition he explicitly says that they are not descended from earlier known dialects, but that they fall into the Western and Eastern groups that the earlier dialects did. We therefore treat the neo-Aramaic dialects as simply descending from the earlier groupings, and not as a coherent group in and of themselves.

child.pub-comments: Rubin belives that Imperial Aramaic should be classifed into two periods: Early Imperial Aramaic (700-550 BC) and Imperial Aramaic (550-200 BC)

child.pub-comments: Rubin in one place has a subgroup "Arabic" (p2) and in anotther "Proto-Arabic" (P7). To distinguish the language rom the subgroup, we use the term "Proto-Arabic".
